title: Systematic Review of RAG Systems (Oche et al., 2025)
content:
This comprehensive systematic review traces RAG evolution from 2017 to 2025, covering technical foundations, year-by-year progress, and enterprise applications.

HISTORICAL TIMELINE:
- 2017-2019: Pre-RAG era - DrQA, R3, ORQA with retrieve-and-read pipelines
- 2020: Birth of RAG (Lewis et al.), DPR, REALM, KILT benchmark
- 2021: Fusion-in-Decoder (FiD), EMDR2, improved multi-passage integration
- 2022-2024: Advanced techniques, enterprise deployment, agentic RAG

TECHNICAL COMPONENTS:
1. Retriever Module: Dense Passage Retrieval (DPR) with bi-encoder architecture
   - Query encoder E_q(x) and passage encoder E_p(d)
   - Similarity via dot product, trained with contrastive loss
   
2. Generator Module: Seq2seq (BART, T5) conditioning on retrieved docs
   - Early fusion: Concatenate all passages
   - Late fusion: Marginalize over documents (RAG-Sequence, RAG-Token)

3. Fusion Strategies:
   - Marginalization (probabilistic fusion)
   - Direct concatenation (Fusion-in-Decoder)
   - Weighted aggregation with attention

RAG FORMULA:
P(y|x) = Σ P_ret(z_i|x) × P_gen(y|x,z_i)

EXECUTION FLOW:
1. Query encoding → 2. Document retrieval → 3. Context preparation → 4. Answer generation → 5. Fusion and output

KEY MILESTONES:
- DPR improved top-20 recall by 9-19% over BM25
- RAG with few hundred million params surpassed 11B closed-book LMs
- FiD allows decoder to attend to multiple documents simultaneously

CHALLENGES IDENTIFIED:
- Retrieval quality and precision
- Privacy concerns with proprietary data
- Integration overhead and latency
- Hallucination despite retrieval
